1: the ability to establish a common direction, influence and motivate others, committing them to action lead·er·ship noun \lē-dar-,ship\
leadership is not telling others what to do. is inspiring others to do what needs to be done! is inspiring others to do what needs to be done! leadership

abraham lincoln 16th u.s. president when the conduct of men is designed to be influenced, persuasion, kind unassuming persuasion, should ever be adopted. it is an old and true maxim that 'a drop of honey catches more flies than a gallon of gall.' so with men. if you would win a man to your cause, first convince him that you are his sincere friend.

ethos credibility with character the art of persuasion 1 pathos emotional persuasion logos logical appeal
credibility the art of persuasion 1 emotions logic

reciprocation do something for others first. the principles of influence 2
commitment provide a solid, consistent example. the principles of influence 2
authority know what you are talking about. the principles of influence 2
social validation the principles of influence 2 we love to be part of a crowd.
friendship a pleasant personality can make up for a multitude of failures. the principles of influence 2
creating an impact 3 more leadership skills = more impact big impact = big positive change

confident bearing/ kindly manner justice/mercy creating an impact 3 intellect/ willingness to learn emotion/self-control communicate/listen rule-follower/ flexibility innovative/realistic commitment/ ability to lead strong commitment to your vision

new management a) put an 'out of order' sign on the bathroom door and count the register. b) ask the employee to count the register and clean up the mess yourself. c) tell the employee to clean up the mess while you count the register.

new management what will you do? a) put an 'out of order' sign on the bathroom door and count the register. b) ask the employee to count the register and clean up the mess yourself. c) tell the employee to clean up the mess while you count the register. submit submit submit
new management you chose to put an "out of order" sign on the bathroom door. if you'd like to try another option, press the 'previous' button below.
new management you chose to clean up the mess yourself, and delegate to your employee.
new management you chose to have your employee clean the mess while you counted the money. if you'd like to try another option, press the 'previous' button below.

creating an action plan

1 2 3 4 5 honest, fair-minded, straightforward inspiring, courageous broad-minded, imaginative independent, mature, dependable forward-looking, ambitious, determined intelligent, competent caring, supportive, loyal cooperative rate yourself again. low high

honest, fair-minded, straightforward inspiring, courageous broad-minded, imaginative independent, mature, dependable forward-looking, ambitious, determined intelligent, competent caring, supportive, loyal cooperative honest, fair-minded, straightforward: practice giving up those little white lies. find ways to tell the truth with tact so that your integrity remains strong. practice being direct and concise in your speech and emails. don't use a lot of words when a few will do and be clear in getting to your point. avoid actions or phrases that may be misleading. inspiring, courageous: watch some of the movies we recommend on great, inspiring leaders, or read some biographies about interesting people. do one thing every day that scares you. if you have a new idea at work, be bold and tell your supervisor about it. if there's someone you've been wanting to speak to but have always been too afraid, make this week the week you do it. broad-minded, imaginative: travel to places where people who are from a different culture or different socio-economic status live. spend a few hours each day dreaming up ideas. keep a sketch book, paints, or a coloring book nearby to spark your creativity and exercise your imagination. independent, mature, dependable: try doing things a little differently than everyone else. work on always making your word your bond. if you say you're going to do something, do it. try not to make plans if you can't keep them, and try not to make promises you can't keep. forward-looking, ambitious, determined: make a plan for the next month. write down some life goals on a piece of paper. things you've always wanted to do, but for some reason feel held back. have grand ideas, even if they seem unrealistic. if there's something you've really been wanting to achieve, make up your mind today to stick to it. don't give up even if it gets hard. try to think of ways to take even the smallest steps and reward yourself for small victories. intelligent, competent: sign-up for more online courses at creativeu or on other educational websites and build your knowledge base. discuss new topics with other users. think of a skill that you've always wanted to learn, and see what certification courses are available. you'll build your competency and add to your resumé. caring, supportive, loyal: volunteer at a nursing home, a kindergarten, or an animal shelter. look out for what other people may need that you can provide for them, be it a meal, a listening ear, or a ride to the store. cooperative: join a team sport or any local club and gain experience cooperating with others in order to achieve a common goal. select an ability to learn how you can improve in this area.

seek inspiration the most successful leaders do 15 things automatically, every day! film: the king's speech film: dave article: "the most successful leaders do 15 things automatically, every day!" may we recommend take action learn about a variety of leaders, including the way they dealt with challenges.

choose a role model type your response here type your response here who will be your role model? what are some of their traits that you admire? take action do some research on leaders in history that left an impression, and choose one that fits your personality. read a biography or find videos on his or her life.
seek experience take action take a leadership role in a social group or club. gain experience working with people on many levels.

create a personal mission statement type your response here type your response here type your response here take action how do you want to be remembered? what do you want people to think of you? what type of leader are you determined to be? write a statement that defines who you will be.

determine your vision what's your vision? take action type your response here think of something you'd like to achieve or see come to pass that you'd be instrumental in bringing about. write this vision down.

specific - answer who, what, when, where, and why. set smart goals for your vision measurable - measure progress, attainment, results achieved, time spent. attainable - break your goals down into attainable steps. realistic - set new, smaller goals to obtain resources if needs permit. write 2 or 3 goals for your vision that are smart. timed - create a time frame to ensure urgency. type your response here
create a long-term plan
create a support system take action assign duties, document forward movement, track progress via checklists or software management systems. we recommend milestone planner.

"the bravest are surely those who have the clearest vision of what is before them, glory and danger alike, and yet notwithstanding, go out and meet it." words from the wise review your action plan! thucydides athenian general during the peloponnesian war

resource_data.description: Here are some useful articles and movies that we recommend for you:

resource.title: “Situational Leadership Theory.” Wikipedia. n.p., 18 Nov. 2013. Web. 2 Dec. 2013.
Tappin, Steve. “Incredible Movies to Inspire Leaders.” Linkedin. n.p., 22 Aug. 2013. Web. 2 Dec. 2013.
Llopis, Glenn. "The Most Successful Leaders Do 15 Things Automatically, Every Day.” Forbes. Forbes.com LLC, 18 Feb. 2013. Web. 2 Dec. 2013.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to Leadership and Influence! They say that leaders are born, not made. While it is true that some people are born leaders, some leaders are created in the midst of adversity.

Leadership potential exists within all of us, it just needs to be explored. By learning the techniques of true leadership, you will acquire confidence and maybe even discover leadership abilities you never knew existed.

In this course, you will learn how to adapt different leadership styles, to utilize the abilities of successful leadership, to employ basic influencing skills, and to create an action plan. At the end of this course, you will have learned how to develop your innate leadership abilities and build the confidence required in being a true leader.
Leadership can be defined as the ability to establish a common direction and influence and motivate others, committing them to action.
Leadership is not telling others what to do. Leadership is inspiring others to do what needs to be done.

Genuine leaders take a stand and motivate others to join them in a noble purpose. For example, Abraham Lincoln ended slavery in the United States.

Take a look at this quote.
The following are a list of common characteristics of leaders. How do you compare? Take a look at the list and rate yourself according to the degree.

There is no real formula to being a leader. Leadership must come from within, and it is based on your personality and the situation at hand.

In the following lesson, we will discuss several different styles that are based on the type of follower.

It is the followers that you want to motivate and influence, so you must take this into account when leading. The Situational Leadership model explores four types of leadership:

Telling
Selling
Participating
Delegating

Telling is the lowest level of leadership style. Most new employees require direct instruction, have low competency and high commitment. The leader must focus on tasks.

Encourage and motivate them, offering praise for positive results and correction for mistakes. The idea is to encourage the follower to rise to the next level of ability.

Selling is a mid-level leadership style that addresses the follower who has developed some competence and shows even more commitment.

The leader must still focus highly on tasks, but should now develop a relationship with the employee. Build upon the growing trust and the encouragement that has been demonstrated.

Engage the follower as a coach would: "tell” less, "suggest" more. Continue to encourage them and recognize when someone has progressed.

Participating is an advanced style of leadership that addresses the follower who is now competent at the job, but remains somewhat inconsistent.

Participate with and support the follower.

The follower may not be convinced yet in his or her ability. At this point, focus less on the tasks assigned and more on the relationship between the follower, the leader, and the group.

Delegating is the ultimate goal:a follower who feels fully empowered and competent enough to accomplish tasks on their own, with minimal supervision.

The leader can now delegate tasks to the follower and observe with minimal follow up, knowing that acceptable or even excellent results will be achieved. There is a low focus on tasks and a low focus on relationships.
Try the following activity. Match each group of followers with the type of leadership style that is most appropriate for the followers' characteristics.

Well done! And since great examples of leadership should always be shared, take a look at this video and gain some inspiration from those who have the courage not only to lead, but also to follow.

YouTube Video on Leadership Lessons from Dancing Guy

Let's do a quick review of the Leadership Styles from the previous module.

Telling: where the followers have low competency, need focused instruction, and high encouragement.

Selling: followers have mid-level competency, the focus is on relationship building, and there's more guidance than telling.

Participating: followers have a higher competency, but need more support with a focus on relationship.

And lastly, there's Delegating. Followers are empowered and capable, need minimal supervision, and there is praise for good performance.

In addition to leadership styles, there are also certain abilities that are able to influence followers and bring them to accept the leader's vision. These abilities are crucial to starting a movement and building momentum.

The book, "The Leadership Challenge," by James Kouzes and Barry Posner, identifies five abilities that are crucial to successful leadership:

Modeling the Way

Inspiring a Shared Vision

Challenging the Process

Enabling Others to Act

Encouraging the Heart

The best leaders are examples of what they want their followers to be and model the way. You cannot remain behind, safe and detached, while you send your followers out to face the challenges. This will eliminate respect.

A leader is right up front, ready to take the heat if something goes wrong. A true leader never blames his followers, even if in fact they failed.

What qualities make some of your favorite leaders successful? How did they deal with adversity? Every leader in history has had failures.

People are often intimidated by confidence, but don't let this hold you back. If you have honesty, integrity and deal with everyone fairly, then others will see that. Be willing to listen to criticism. Don't be afraid of what others might say about you, and don't ignore legitimate complaints solely because of your position.

Always present an honest, caring, dedicated attitude to inspire loyalty in others. If your followers feel they have been wronged, address the issue immediately.

Sometimes, the most powerful influence you can have is listening. When people believe you are open to their suggestions and believe they are being heard, they will work harder. That is the power of listening: it makes people feel empowered. If you go the extra mile, your followers are more likely to go the extra mile. Don't hide in your office. Be seen!
Inspire a shared vision among your followers. Before you can do this, you have to develop it. Be clear in your vision, live it so that others can see it, and model it from your behavior.

What do you want to accomplish, and what do you need to do to get there? Determine attainable goals and focus on them. Your vision will provide direction for you and your followers. It should be like a lighthouse on a hill, guiding ships to safety and warning them away from the rocks.

Communication is more than just words. Remember, actions speak louder. Take every opportunity to communicate your vision in both words and deeds. Sum it up in a simple catch phrase. Above all, lead by example.

Answer the question, “What’s in it for me?” as if you were one of your own followers. Most followers enjoy being part of a larger, successful organization. We are social creatures who like to feel like we belong. If you can get your followers to accept your vision as their own, and excite them about being part of it, they will often excel beyond what you (or they) thought possible. When they do excel, be sure to reward them.

Challenge the process and don’t continue doing something just because “We’ve always done it that way.” Situations change, and sometimes a policy or procedure never worked well in the first place. As a leader, search out opportunities to change, grow, innovate, and improve. Experiment, take risks, and learn from any mistakes. Ask questions, even if you fear the answers.

Sometimes an established model works quite well, but often they are inadequate or counterproductive. Sometimes you must “think outside the box." Don’t be afraid to ask “Why?” Ask questions of your followers, employees, customers, and former leaders.

Innovation is more than just improvement; it is a total restructuring. Innovators reverse policies and procedures based on the new vision and goals, working from the target backwards. Change should never be made simply for the sake of change. Plan your innovations carefully. There should be solid evidence that a new way of doing things is likely to work. Focus on the goals and be willing to break the rules if they need to be broken, but don’t break something that needs to keep working! With proper research and planning, you can dare to be bold!

A strong vision does not lend itself to mediocrity. A drive to excellence always seeks improvement. Goals must not be unrealistic or unattainable, or so low that little or no effort is required to meet it.

Set high goals for your vision that are attainable but with some degree of difficulty, and reward those who meet them.

To lobby for change, you need to influence people and excite them to your vision. Demonstrate why your requested change needs to occur.

Do your research and always be prepared. Give people something they can easily understand. But don't overload people with facts. Show as clearly as possible how your plan will effect positive change.

Whatever the situation, you can successfully lobby for change if you attack the problem with a plan, sound reasoning, and infectious enthusiasm!

Enabling others to act is the ultimate goal of the situational leadership model: to develop your followers to the point where you can delegate tasks without a lot of oversight.

You must enable others to act responsibly and not encourage bad habits by overlooking them. The goal is to empower others to work.

A positive attitude is essential to encouraging growth in others. No one likes to fail and many take it personally, but the focus should never be on the fall, but on the getting up. The goal is to walk…then to run.
You will never be worthy of respect if you don’t give respect. Respect should be given to everyone at all levels unless they deliberately do something to lose that respect.

Respect inevitably leads to trust. Do what you say and say what you mean. If people feel they can rely on you, they will trust you.

Let people know that you are not asking them to do anything you would not do yourself. Work hard and be seen working hard.

Lastly, always remember that people have intellect and emotions and are not simply resources. Remember to deal with them person to person and encourage their hearts. This will go a long way in inspiring loyalty.

Since your followers are sharing in the work, make sure they also share in the rewards. Don't take all the credit for completing a successful task, but celebrate their accomplishments as well. Set team milestones and give public recognition when they're met.
Let's think back to our dancing man and how he exemplifies qualities of leadership. Take this quiz to see if you can tell how the characters in the video exhibit the different leadership abilities.
Well done! Now, you can take what you've learned and apply it to your own situation.

Let's review what it means to utilize crucial leadership abilities. A successful leader should model the way by leading by example; should be clear and live the vision; think outside the box; encourage growth and create mutual respect; treat people as humans and introduce celebration.

In this module, we will learn about the skills of influence. The best leaders are able to influence others to do something and think it was all their idea. Don’t worry about taking credit for every good thing that happens on your watch.

As the leader, you get credit whenever your followers succeed because you created the environment that allowed their success.

One of the most important influencing skills is the art of persuasion. Aristotle was a master at it, and in his work, "Rhetoric," he outlines three important factors in persuasion: ethos, pathos, and logos.

Ethos (credibility) persuades people using character. If you are respectful and honest, people will be more likely to follow you because of your character. Your character convinces the follower that you are someone who is worth listening to for advice.

Pathos (emotional) persuades people by appealing to their emotions. but be careful. It can be easily abused, leading to a loss of Ethos, as described before.

Logos (logical) persuades people by appealing to their intellect. Also a very useful tool, but not everyone reacts on a rational level.
Of the three, Ethos, or credibility, must always come first. Ideally, you want to appeal to the emotional, back your arguments up with logic, and never lose credibility.

Robert B. Cialdini, Ph. D. once said, "It is through the influence process that we generate and manage change.” He outlined five universal principles of influence: reciprocation, commitment, authority, social validation, and friendship.
People are more willing to do something for you if you have already done something for them first.
You cannot get people to commit to you or your vision if they don’t see your commitment. Once you provide a solid, consistent example, they will feel they have to do the same.

If people believe you know what you are talking about and accept your expertise, they are far more likely to follow you. Despite the rebel cry, “Question Authority,” when people need help with something, they will seek out an authority figure.

As independent as we like to consider ourselves, we love to be part of a crowd. It will always be a part of us, that school age desire to be accepted. People will always jump on a bandwagon if their friends like the band.
People listen to their friends. If they know you and like you, they are far more likely to support you. A pleasant personality can make up for a multitude of failures.

As mentioned before, communication is accomplished with more than just words. The more leadership skills you develop, the more you will make an impact. In addition, the bigger the impact, the greater the positive change you can create.

Impact is created by a number of tangible factors:

A confident bearing, tempered by a kindly manner

A strong sense of justice, tempered by mercy

A strong intellect, tempered by the willingness to learn

A strong sense of emotion, tempered by self-control

A strong ability to communicate, tempered by the ability to listen

A strong insistence on following the rules, tempered by flexibility

A strong commitment to innovation, tempered by situational reality

A strong commitment to your followers, tempered by the ability to lead

Above all: maintain a strong personal commitment to your vision.
Now let's take everything you've learned so far about great leadership and provide you with a real world situation where what you've learned has to be put into practice.

This is you. You've just been promoted to manager over your peers after working a year at a small café.

There are a lot of customers waiting in line, and the cash register is full and needs to be counted.

One of the toilets is overflowing, making quite a mess, and your maintenance person is busy fixing an emergency electric problem.

One of your more experienced, trustworthy employees is just coming off of her break. What do you do?

A) Close the restroom for the time being, putting an “Out of Order” sign on the door so your employee can help with the line of customers and you can count the registers.

B) Ask the employee to count the register while you clean up the mess with the toilet yourself.

C) Tell the employee coming in to clean up the mess with the toilet while you go and count the register and make change.

You've successfully managed the current issues, there's now plenty of change in the register and your employees are satisfied, but you are now approached by a pregnant woman who urgently needs to use the bathroom, causing another problem that has to be solved.

You know how to delegate and participate, enable and lead by example - you’ve shown you trust and respect the employee to handle an important task while also showing your willingness to do any of the unpleasant tasks that you would ask your employees to do. This method solves the issues and builds trust, respect, and loyalty in your employees.

By directing, you've solved all the issues; however, the employee is now grudgingly doing the dirty task, mumbling all the while how had this happened last week, you would have been the one cleaning the toilet.

Not as easy as you'd think, is it? Sometimes we find ourselves having to manage multiple problems and people while still trying to exemplify traits of a good leader. Keep these things in mind as we move on to Creating an Action plan in Module 4.

Last module, we talked about the importance of influence, beginning with Art of Persuasion:
Ethos, Pathos, and Logos.
Appeal to the emotions, back up the claim with logic, but never lose credibility.

We also discussed the five principles of influence and learned how to combine leadership characteristics to create an impact.

In this last and final module, you're going to create an action plan to help you analyze your own innate
leadership abilities and also to motivate you to move forward and become a stronger leader in the future.

First of all, think back to that list of leadership characteristics on which you rated yourself before.
Now that you've learned a little more about exercising these characteristics in every day situations, rate yourself again. What do you think of your own leadership characteristics now?
Here are some practical ideas to get you thinking about how you can strengthen these characteristics within yourself.

In conclusion, we have a few action items we'd like you to consider:

Seek Inspiration

Imagine your legacy.

How do you want to be remembered?
What do you want people to think of you?
What type of leader are you determined to be?

Now that you've thought a little more about what type of leader you want to be,
determine your vision.

Set SMART goals for your vision. Specific, measurable, attainable, realistic, and timed.

First, goals should be specific targets to be met.

Second, goals must be measurable in terms of progress and attainment.

Third, goals must be attainable. A goal that cannot be met is not a goal, it's an ideal.

A goal must also be realistic and you need to obtain the resources.

Lastly, all goals need a sense of urgency, and each should lead to the next step in the overall plan until the ultimate vision is reached.

A long-term plan is the road map that will guide you to the realization of your vision.

You may be missing key elements in the larger goals that need to be met through smaller, planned goals along the way.

Once your goals are established you need a way to ensure they are set into motion.

Whatever it is, be sure to have some kind of monitoring system in place.

Believe it or not, you are well on your way to achieving the goals that will lead to you achieving your vision!
Review your Action Plan!

Remember, to be a leader, you must first see yourself as a leader.

You have learned what qualities are important in a leader, what qualities you already possess, and what qualities you'd like to work on.

Experience is the greatest teacher, however, and there is no substitute.

So get out there, be bold, go after your vision, and be the leader that you would love to follow!
